titleStmt.title: Proposals for the printing an entire course or body of philosophy, according to the principles of the famous Renate Des Cartes, wrote in Latin by the learned Anthony Le Grand which will now be carefully translated into English by good hands, with large additions and alterations by the said author, and printed in folio, with an illustration of about an hundred ornamental scultptures / by Richard Blome, dwelling near Clare-market in New Weld-street, at the house with green pallisado-pails; where proposals are delivered and subscriptions taken for the same, and where they may inspect the said work.
titleStmt.author: Blome, Richard, d. 1705.

titleStmt.title: Proposals for the printing an entire course or body of philosophy, according to the principles of the famous Renate Des Cartes, wrote in Latin by the learned Anthony Le Grand which will now be carefully translated into English by good hands, with large additions and alterations by the said author, and printed in folio, with an illustration of about an hundred ornamental scultptures / by Richard Blome, dwelling near Clare-market in New Weld-street, at the house with green pallisado-pails; where proposals are delivered and subscriptions taken for the same, and where they may inspect the said work.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: PROPOSALS FOR THE Printing an entire Cour≈øe or Body of PHILOSOPHY, according to the Principles of the Famous Renate Des Cartes; Wrote in Latin by the Learned Anthony Le Grand; which will now be carefully Tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh by Good Hands, with large Additions and Alterations by the ≈øaid Author, and Printed in Folio, with an Illu≈øtration of about an Hundred Ornamental Sculptures, ≈øuitable to the ≈øeveral Subjects; By Richard Blome, dwelling near Clare-Market in New Weld-≈øtreet at the Hou≈øe with Green Palli≈øado Pails; where Propo≈øals are delivered and Sub≈øcriptions taken for the ≈øame, and where they may in≈øpect the ≈øaid Work.
div.p: THe Books of this Learned and much e≈øteemed Anthony Le Grand, now to be publi≈øhed in Engli≈øh, are the In≈øtitution of PHILOSOPHY, the Hi≈øtory of NATURE, and a Di≈øcour≈øe of BRUTES: Which ≈øaid Books have been ≈øo well received by the Learned, that ≈øeveral Impre≈ø≈øions have been made and vended here in England, and in Forein Countries. And now to this Great Work, the ≈øaid Author for the publick Good has made ≈øuch large Additions, as well as Alterations therein, that nothing material is wanting to make it an entire Body of Philo≈øophy, and is rendred ≈øo facile as to be of u≈øe and delight to the meane≈øt Capacities. And for the making this Work the more acceptable to the Curious, it ≈øhall be Illu≈øtrated with about 100 Sculptures di≈øper≈øed through the Work, to ≈øuch Chapters as be≈øt admit thereof; all de≈øigned and drawn Hi≈øtorically by good Arti≈øts. And be≈øides the ≈øaid Ornamental Sculptures, there are great variey of Schemes for the Explanation of the Philo≈øophical Parts that require the ≈øame.

This Work, as afore≈øaid, is divided into Three Books: The fir≈øt treats of the In≈øtitutions in 10 Sections or Parts; Fir≈øt, Of Logick, divided into 23 Chapters. Secondly, Natural Theology, or Metaphy≈øicks, in 16 Chapters. Thirdly, Daemology and Created Spirits, in 11 Chapters. Fourthly, Of Natural Philo≈øophy in general, and of Bodies, in 25 Chapters. Fifthly of Special Natural Philo≈øophy of the World and Heaven, in 23 Chapters. Sixthly, Of the four great Bodies, viz. the Earth, Water, Air and Fire, in 23 Chapters. Seventhly, Of Living Creatures in general, as Fourfooted Bea≈øts, Creeping things, Birds, Fi≈øh and In≈øects, and in particular of Plants, in 23 Chapters. Eighthly, Of Man, as it re≈øpects his Body, in 23 Chapters. Ninthly, Of Man, as to his Mind, Affections or Pa≈ø≈øions of the Soul, in 14 Chapters. And, Tenthly, Of Ethicks or Moral Philo≈øophy, treating of the right ordering of a Mans life, &c. in 37 Chapters.

The ≈øecond Book, viz. the Hi≈øtory of NATURE, in 9 Parts, which illu≈øtrates the fir≈øt Book of the In≈øtitutes, and con≈øi≈øts of great variety of Experiments, relating to the ≈øeveral Parts thereof, and explained by the ≈øame Principles.
The third Book is the Tract or Di≈øcour≈øe of Brutes, giving a Mechanical Account of their Operations.

The French for ≈øome years pa≈øt have Printed their Books in their own Language, which has been a very great improvement to real Learning and Knowledge, even in the Female Sex, to their great commendation, and much to the Honour of the Nation; which Rea≈øons may be ≈øufficient for the Printing this Work in our Native Tongue.

And as this Work can't but be acknowledged by all, to be of great u≈øe for the advancement of real Learning, as well as Entertaining and Plea≈øant, ≈øo 'tis hoped Encouragement will not be wanting chearfully to embolden the Undertaker, Richard Blome, to fini≈øh the ≈øame; wherefore he humbly tenders the≈øe Propo≈øals.

list.head: The PROPOSALS.
list.item: 1. Tho≈øe that plea≈øe, for the Advancement of ≈øo good a Work, to Sub≈øcribe and pay to the ≈øaid Richard Blome, or his lawful A≈ø≈øigns, by Writing under his Hand and Seal, Fifty Shillings, ≈øhall have one of the ≈øaid Books in Sheets; Twenty Shillings to be paid the ≈øaid Richard Blome, when about half the Book is printed, if ≈øo required by the ≈øaid Richard Blome, upon the delivery of a Receipt under the Hand and Seal of the ≈øaid Richard Blome, and the remainder to be paid on delivery thereof in Sheets. And ≈øuch as are curious in their Books, may have them of a finer ≈øort of Paper gracefully Ruled and carefully Bound, or the Sculptures illu≈øtrated in Colours, paying the Charges thereof.

II. Such as for the further Encouragement of this Work, will be greater Benefactors, ≈øhall according to their genero≈øity have one or more of the ≈øaid Books, as afore≈øaid, with a Memorial of their Arms and Titles (≈øo as allowed by the Heralds) Engraven either at the beginning of the Book, or to a Sculpture as Patron thereof, to remain to future Ages, as Promoters to ≈øo good a Work; and if to a Sculpture, then at the beginning of the Book al≈øo. And it is de≈øired that the Mony ≈øo ≈øub≈øcribed above 50 s. the price of the Book, be advanced to the ≈øaid Richard Blome, for and towards the ≈øaid Charges of the Arms and Sculpture, for which a Receipt ≈øhall be given by the ≈øaid Richard Blome, under his Hand and Seal.
III. Such as procure Sub≈øcriptions for Six of the ≈øaid Books, ≈øhall upon the payment of the Mony due for the ≈øame, have one of the ≈øaid Books in Sheets pre≈øented them gratis.

div.p: Altho' the Subject of this Work is very u≈øeful and delightful, and performed by ≈øo good an Author, and Illu≈øtrated with ≈øuch great variety of Sculptures, all done by the ≈øaid Author's Directions, ≈øuitable to the Subjects, and that the Book is ≈øet at ≈øo low a rate; yet con≈øidering the badne≈øs of the Times, and the great Charge in Printing, there will be but a very ≈ømall Impre≈ø≈øion made, which will be Printed by Michaelma≈øs Term, 1693.

Sub≈øcriptions being a voluntary Act and Encouragement, if performed, 'tis de≈øired that none Sub≈øcribe, but ≈øuch as will readily recieve their Books, and pay the Mony according to the Propo≈øals by them Contracted for.

For Advancement of the ≈øaid Work, I promi≈øe to receive of the ≈øaid Richard Blome, his Executors or A≈ø≈øigns, One of the Books, and pay the Sum of _____ according to the Propo≈øal; Witne≈øs my Hand this _____ day of
_____ Anno Domini 169 _____

div.head: An Account of the ≈øaid WORK.
div.p: ANd fora≈ømuch as PHILOSOPHY, the Subject of this Work is of ≈øo copious an extent, comprehending the Nature, &c. of all Things that the Mind of Man is capable of knowing: Therefore for the better ≈øatisfying of ≈øuch as de≈øire to be Sub≈øcribers, 'tis thought convenient to give a ≈øhort Account of the principal Heads therein Treated of.

This Work is divided into Three BOOKS; The fir≈øt, The In≈øtitutions of Philo≈øophy: The Second, The Hi≈øtory of Nature: And the Third, A Di≈øcour≈øe of Brutes. The In≈øtitutions is divided into 10 Parts, and tho≈øe into ≈øeveral Chapters.

The Fir≈øt Part is of Logick, which the Author calleth the Organ or In≈øtrument of all Philo≈øophy: It is divided into 4 Parts, and tho≈øe into 23 Chapters, and treats, Fir≈øt, Which are the Ob≈øtacles to the attaining of Science, and how to be removed. Rules for attaining Truth. Nothing is admitted for Truth, which includes any Doubt. Not to rely too much on the Sen≈øes. What≈øoever we ≈øee clearly and di≈øtinctly, is true. The various manners of Perception. Of the Five Univer≈øals examin'd, as to their nature, properties and u≈øe. Of Sub≈øtance, and its affectives or modes. Of the common Attributes of Sub≈øtance. How Sub≈øtance agrees to God, and the Creatures. The Genealogy of Things and Modes, Cau≈øes and Effects, Subjects and Adjuncts, of the di≈øtinctions, whence the natures and differences of Idea's are deduced. Secondly, Of Judgment Ab≈øolute and Comparative. What a Propo≈øition is, and how many ≈øorts there are. Of Truth and Fal≈øhood. Of Propo≈øitions, Definitions, and Divi≈øion. Thirdly, Of the Ratiocination of the Mind. Of Rea≈øoning or Argumentation. Of ≈øimple Syllogi≈øms, and tho≈øe either complext or incomplext, conjoyn'd or compound. Of Demon≈øtration, Topical Sylogi≈øms, and Sophi≈øtical. Of Places or Topicks whence the Medium Term is fetch'd. Fourthly, Of Method, or orderly ranking our Thoughts. Of the general and ≈øpecial Method of Knowing. The Method of Compo≈øing; and Rules of Definitions and Axioms.

The Second Part treats of Natural Theology, or Metaphy≈øicks, which is divided into 16 Chapters. Fir≈øt, An Introductory Di≈øcour≈øe, its definition and certainty. What God is‚ñ™ and how known by us, which appears by the inborn Idea we have of him. That Exi≈øtence doth nece≈ø≈øarily belong to God, which is deducible from the contemplation of the Things of this World. Of Fate, and that it puts no force on the Will. Of Divine Attributes; and fir≈øt of the Unity of God, that he is Eternal, Immen≈øe, not circum≈øcribed in any one place, the mo≈øt ≈øimple Being; that he is True, and can't deceive nor be deceived; that he is Supream and All-knowing; that he is Good and doth Good; is Almighty, the Creatour and Governour of all things.

The Third Part; of Created Spirits, Angels, and Demons; which is divided into 11 Chapters, and treats of the divi≈øion of Created Beings. The Doctrin of Spirits. What the Nature of Angels is. Whether the Exi≈øtence of Angels is demon≈øtrable by the light of Nature. The Faculties of Angels, as to their Under≈øtanding, Will and Power, to move, produce, or a≈ø≈øume Bodies; their Number, Distinction, and Subordination; whether they be in a place, talk together, and of their Care over Mankind and the≈øe inferiour Beings.

The Fourth Part: Of Natural Philo≈øophy in General, which is divided into 25 Chapters, and treats of the E≈ø≈øence and Certainty of Natural Philo≈øophy. The Exi≈øtence of Material Bodies. Of the Nature of Matter or Body. Of the properties of extended Sub≈øtance; its divi≈øibility and impenetrability. The divi≈øion of Matter into ≈øen≈øible and in≈øen≈øible Parts. The Threefold kind of Matter, and that there are but three Elements of the World. That there are no material Forms in Bodies. Whether there be any Qualities or real Accidents. What intelligible Forms may be attributed to Natural things. The Nature of Rarefaction. The heavine≈øs and lightne≈øs of Bodies. Of Place. The Nature of Motion. Of the Motions a≈ø≈øigned to Nature's endeavouring to avoid a Vacuum. Of the ≈øimple and compound determination of Motion. Of Reflection, and Refraction. The force of Action and Re≈øi≈øtance. The ≈øtate of Bodies, as tho≈øe hard and fluid. Their rarity and den≈øity, roughne≈øs, ≈ømoothne≈øs, &c. and that there are Pores as well in fluid and thin Bodies, as in hard and con≈øi≈øtent. Of Duration, Time and Eternity.

The Fifth Part; Of Special Natural Philo≈øophy, of the World and Heaven, which is divided into 23 Chapters, and treats of the Unity and Perfection of the World; its Form, &c. That GOD, as he is the efficient and con≈øerving Cau≈øe of Matter, ≈øo likewi≈øe of Motion. The Action of Bodies, and the Communication of Motions. Of the Ptolomaick, Copernican, or Tychonick Sy≈øtems of the World, and of the true Sy≈øtem of the Univer≈øe. That the Heavens are fluid Bodies. How the Heavens were ranged at fir≈øt, and of their different Motions. The Action and Motion of Cele≈øtial Matter. Of the Cele≈øtial Globe and its Circles. Of the Sun. Of Light and Refulgency, and how Spots come about the Sun, and the rea≈øon of their Vani≈øhing. Of Comets. Of the Original and Affections of Planets. The Principal of the Planets motion; and of their ≈øtation, direction, and retrogradation. Of the Moons motion, and its various Appearances. Of Eclip≈øes of the Sun and Moon. Of the fixed Stars, and their Influences. And of Judicial A≈øtrology.

The Sixth Part; Of the Four great Bodies, the Earth, Water, Air and Fire, and what mixt and compound Bodies proceed from them. This Part is divided into 24 Chapters; and fir≈øt, of the Original of the Earth, and its Figure; that the Earth is moved by the fluid Heaven, which ≈øurrounds it. An An≈øwer to Aristotles, and others Objections again≈øt the Motion of the Earth. Of the Vi≈øibility of Day and Night, and the Sea≈øons. Of the Zones, and their Inhabitants; and of the Climates. Of things generated in the Earth, as Fountains, Metals, Minerals, &c. The Productions of Stones common and precious, and of their difference. Of the Load-Stone, and its virtue whereby it draws Iron. Of the Water, the Flowing and Ebbing of the Sea. Of the Nature of the Air. Of the Elastick force of the Air. Of Meteors, and fir≈øt of the Wind. Of Rain, Dew and Hoar-fro≈øt. Of Snow and Hail. Of Thunder and Lightning. Of the Rainbow. Of Fire, and the Nature of Heat and Cold. Of the various effects of Fire, and among≈øt them of Earthquakes. Of the Mixtion of Bodies, as al≈øo of their Changes, viz. Generation, Corruption, Alteration, Augmentation and Diminution.

The Seventh Part; of Living Creatures in General, and in Particular of Plants. This Part is divided into 23 Chapters. Of the Divi≈øion of Living things. How Living Bodies differ from tho≈øe without Life. That Bodily Life con≈øi≈øts in heat and moisture, and that their Death proceeds from the contrary Principles of cold and drine≈øs. Whence the hardne≈øs proceeds that is found in the out≈øide of Living things. Of the diver≈øity of Heat in Living Bodies. Of the virtue and nature of Food that abides in the Bodies, that are fed by them. That Living things are changed according to the diver≈øity of Time and Place. Of Plants, as to their Original, Nutrition, Growth, Difference and Propagation, by Grafting; their colour, ta≈øte, ≈ømell, &c. Of the di≈øea≈øes and death of Plants. Of Animals. Of the Soul of Brute Bea≈øts, and what it is. Of Four footed Bea≈øts and Creeping Things. Of Birds, Fi≈øh and In≈øects; and of the death of Animals.

The Eighth Part; of Man, with re≈øpect to his Body; which is divided into 24 Chapters. The definition of MAN. The outward and inward Parts of Man's Body. The forming of the Birth in the Womb, the configuration of its Parts, and the vivifying or animation of the Compound. How the Body is Nouri≈øhed. How the Motions of the Heart, Arteries and Mu≈øcles in the Body is performed. Of the Circulation of the Blood. Of Re≈øpiration. Of the growth and decrea≈øe of Mans Body. Of its Temperaments, and different Ages. Of the Sen≈øes in general, and in particular of each, viz. Feeling, Ta≈øting, Smelling, Hearing and Seeing; of the Eye, of Colours, and how the Sight is performed. Of Watching and Sleep. Of Hunger and Thir≈øt. Of the common Sen≈øe of Imagination and Memory. Of Health and Sickne≈øs; of Medicine in general, and of their Operations.

The Ninth Part; of MAN, con≈øidered with re≈øpect to his Mind; which is divided into 14 Chapters, and treats of the
Nature of the Mind of Man, and that it is more evidently known than the Body. That the Mind is di≈øtinct from the Body, and that the ≈øame is Spiritual or Immortal. Whether there be any inborn Idea's in the Mind. Of its Faculties, viz. Under≈øtanding, Imagination, Will and Memory. Of the Affections or Pa≈ø≈øions of the Soul. In what part of the Body the Soul feels its Pa≈ø≈øions. Of the number and order of the Pa≈ø≈øions. Of Wonder or Admiration; of Love and Hatred; of De≈øire or Longing; and of Joy and Sorrow. Whence the Natural Inclinations and Aver≈øions of ≈øome Men ari≈øe. Of the Immortality of Mans Mind, and its state after Death.

The Tenth Part, treating of the
‚Ä¢ ight Ordering of Mans Life; which is divided into 37 Chapters. It begins with an Introduction of the worth and u≈øe of Ethicks, or Moral Philo≈øophy, the Subject of this Part. Of the nature and principal Parts thereof. What Good is, and how and why it is de≈øired. That the good things of the Body do not conduce to the Happine≈øs of Man. That outward Good things are not for his Good. What is the highe≈øt Good in this Life, and his ultimate End. Of Vertue in general. Of the Law of Nature and right Rea≈øon, and the Practical dictates thereof; of Prudence, Temperance, Fortitude and Ju≈øtice. Of the u≈øefulne≈øs of the Pa≈ø≈øions of the Soul; and of Admiration. Of the end of Love and Hatred, and their Interpretations. Of the u≈øe of De≈øire, Joy and Sorrow. Of the government of the Pa≈ø≈øions, and their Remedies. Of Mans Liberty; how they continue Free notwith≈øtanding God's Power; and whether the Liberty of his Will can be hindred. Of Human Actions, and the goodne≈øs and pravity of them. Of the Duties of Man in general, and of a good Citizen in particular. Of the Rule of Human Actions. Of Man's Duty towards God, and towards him≈øelf. Laws to be ob≈øerved with re≈øpect to other Men, as to Bargains, Contracts, or the like; and by what means Obligations may be broken. Laws that re≈øpect Speaking and Swearing. Of Dominion, and the Duties or Offices thence ari≈øing. Of the Duty of Married People; the like of Parents and Children, Masters and Servants. Of the Right of Dominion, and its different Forms, viz. Monarchy, Ari≈øtocracy and Democracy. Of the Duties of Sovereign Lords, and the Duties of Citizens.

The Second BOOK, viz. the Hi≈øtory of Nature, which Illu≈øtrates the Fir≈øt Book of the In≈øtitutions, and con≈øi≈øts of great variety of Experiments relating to the ≈øeveral Parts thereof, and explained by the ≈øame Principles. This Book is divided into Nine Parts, and ≈øubdivided into ≈øeveral Articles or Heads. The Fir≈øt Part treats of Bodies, viz. an extended Body in general. Of Epicurus his Rea≈øons for Vacuities, &c. The Experiments by which Ca≈ø≈øendus a≈ø≈øerted Vacuities, di≈øcu≈øt. Of Bodies divi≈øible, rarified and den≈øe; hard and fluid, rough and ≈ømooth, tran≈øparent and opaque, bent and comprest. The Second Part treats of Qualities, viz. of Qualities in general; of Heat, Cold, Gravity and Lightne≈øs; of Ta≈øte, of Smelling, of Sound, of Light, of Heat, and of hidden Qualities. The Third Part treats of the Earth and Heaven, viz. concerning the Beginning of the World; of the generation of Things, and the di≈øpo≈øure of all its Parts; of the generation and corruption of Things; of Heaven, of the Sun, of fixed Stars, of the Moon; of Spots in the Sun, Moon, and fixed Stars; of Comets; of the production of Stars, and of A≈øtrological Predictions. The Fourth Part treats of Earth, Water, Fire and Air; viz. of the Terre≈øtrial Globe; of the Waters, and the properties of certain Waters; of Fountains and Rivers; of the Sea, its Flux and Reflux; of Fire, of Earthquakes and ≈øubterranean Fires; of Gla≈øs, of A≈øhes and Coals; and of the Air. The Fifth Part treats of Minerals and Metals, viz. of Metals in general; of Mercury and Sulphur; of Salt, of Gold, Silver, Tin, Lead, Bra≈øs and Iron; of the various generations of Stones; of Gems; and of the Load-Stone. The Sixth Part treats of Meteors, viz. of Vapours and Exhalations; of the Wind, of Clouds, Rain, Hail and Snow, Dew and Hony; of Tempe≈øt and Thunder; of Lightning, of the Rainbow, of Fire and Air kindled; of Circles about the Moon, and of counterfeit or Mock-Suns. The Seventh Part treats of Plants, viz. their production and ≈øtrength; their obvious and occult Qualities; their Sympathy and Antipathy; their Birth, Nouri≈øhment, Generation and Death. The Eighth Part treats of Animals, viz. of Animals begot; of Living Creatures produced from Seed; of Mon≈øters; of the Birth of Animals; of Hunger and Thirst; of the Motion of the Heart, and Circulation of the Blood; of the Actions of Animals; of the aver≈øion and agreement of Animals; of Sleep and Watchfulne≈øs; and of Di≈øea≈øes of Animals. The Ninth Part, which treats of Man, viz. of the Sen≈øes of Feeling, Ta≈øting, Smelling, Hearing and Seeing; of Imagination, and Memory; of Dreams; of external Pa≈ø≈øions; and of the natural Inclinations and Aver≈øions.
The Third BOOK, is a Tract or Di≈øcour≈øe of Brutes; giving a Mechanical Account of their Operations, &c.

div.head: An Account of ≈øome Volumes which the Nobility and Gentry may be accommodated with, that were Printed for the ≈øaid Richard Blome, dwelling in New Weld≈øtreet, as afore≈øaid; as al≈øo by the aforementioned Book≈øellers: Viz.
div.p: THe Gentleman's Recreation, in Two Parts, in large Folio. The fir≈øt, of the Liberal and Mathematical Sciences; which in a brief and clear Method treats of the Doctrin and general Parts of each Art, with Eliptical Tables engraven on Copper Plates, for the better comprehending the ≈øame. The Second Part at large treats of Hor≈øman≈øhip, Hawking, Hunting, Fowling, Fi≈øhing and Agriculture; all being Collected from the mo≈øt Authentick Authors, and the many gro≈øs Errors therein Corrected, with great Enlargements made by tho≈øe well Experienced therein. And for the better Explanation thereof great variety of u≈øeful Sculptures, as Nets, Engins, Traps, &c. are added for the taking of Beasts, Fowl and Fi≈øh, not Publi≈øhed by any: Nothing material being omitted for the rendring them compleat. The ≈øaid Richard Blome is now Reprinting a u≈øeful Volume of Co≈ømography and Geography, in Two Parts in Folio The Fir≈øt, of the Arts of Co≈ømography and Geography, being a Tran≈ølation of the much E≈øteemed VARENIUS.
